activity-description.narrative: To break social deprivation and improve opportunities for disabled individuals

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

• Number of disabled men and women who are provided with skills and tools. Develop a policy advisory note on local action for national follow up of Article 30 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Disabled and the inclusion of recommendations in national planning instruments.

comment.narrative: Government of Turkey ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Disabled Persons on 28/9/29009, however there is no policy and local action on the for national follow up of Article 30 on the social integration of disabled people through arts, leisure, sports, recreation and cultural activities.
The activities of Dreams Academies in Kas and Istanbul will reach 1,000 direct beneficiaries. Awareness and advocacy campaigns on disability will target over 20,000 people.
908 people attended the trainings in total. Social media activities, arts exhibitions and concerts of Social Inclusion Band were followed by 15,000 people.

The activities of Dreams Academies in Kas and Istanbul will reach further 1,000 direct beneficiaries. Awareness and advocacy campaigns on disability will target over 20,000 people. A new facility will be created in Sariyer to function as third Dreams Academy.

746 people attended the activities of Dreams Academy. Dreams Shop was formed as a social enterprise model, which will generate income for the continuity of the Project. The facility was not provided by the municipality, despite earlier consent. Therefore, the project focused on the creation of a social enterprise (Dreams Market) within Atasehir facility.
The project is closed therefore no target for Y2017.

activity-description.narrative: To improve energy efficiency of the Turkish industry by enabling and encouraging companies in the industrial sector for efficient management of energy use by different energy conservation measures and energy efficient technologies.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

1. Number of MOENR/TSE/KOSGEB personal training on energy efficiency and audits. 2. Assessment of availability of benchmark data for industrial sectors. 3. Identification of financial mechanisms. 4. Number of ‘Walk-through’ energy audits.

comment.narrative: Turkey has come a long way in setting up the regulatory and institutional framework to promote energy efficiency, including a National Energy Efficiency Strategy and Energy Efficiency Law. Based on this framework, efforts have been made to improve energy efficiency (EE) in energy-intensive sectors such as steel, cement and paper. However, these efforts were largely made by the companies of the designated energy- intensive sectors only and the dissemination of the efforts and outputs of EE needs concerted efforts covering all industry, especially including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that form the bulk of industrial enterprises in Turkey. Various finance, capacity, technology and policy barriers still stand in the way of the widespread adoption of energy-efficient processes and technologies.

description.narrative: To improve energy efficiency of the Turkish industry by enabling and encouraging companies in the industrial sector for efficient management of energy use by different energy conservation measures and energy efficient technologies
A Energy savings from EE investments in industrial sector compared to baseline

comment.narrative: Technical energy savings potential in industry estimated at around 20
At least 190 GWh per year energy and fuel

Initially anticipated energy savings numbers were reviewed as the analytical part of the baseline study that could not be completed before To undertake this task a consultant was hired The consultant elaborated on the baseline energy consumption patterns of the industrial subsectors By using both top down and bottom up approaches both energy intensity and specific energy consumption data he recalculated all the baseline data Relying on this method and the revised past data he also fulfilled energy consumption forecasts The findings were shared withappreciated by all project partners The consultant is currently developing alternative scenarios to calculate the possible energy and CO2 savings through the project activities
No actual energy savings to date Energy savings from EE investments will be measured after the other activities of the project will result in actual investments There are some means for this aim such as i energy audits ii developing energy management units in organized industrial zones iii technical expertlevel trainings in which industrial companies attend for establishing energy management system in their facilities On those 3 topics there are certain progress i The pilot audit program was initiated ii The OIZs were selected and equipment tender is ongoing iii The call for expertlevel training was completed and the dates were determined Despite all mentioned progress a little more time is needed to see the actual investments
It is possible there were some investments resulting from the initial EnMS training however those savings would most likely be minimal at this point

description.narrative: B Direct and indirect emission reductions

comment.narrative: GHG emissions from industry were around 665 MktCO2 in 2009 and are projected to grow to 1153 MtCO2 by 2025

Direct emission reduction associated with demo projects of 609 ktCO2 pa and assuming an average 10year lifetime of energy investment 609 ktCO2 cumulatively
Cumulative indirect emission reduction due to projects capacity building activities ranging from 18 MtCO2 bottomup approach to 327 MtCO2 topdown

No actual emission savings to date Emission savings from EE investments will be measured after the other activities of the project will result in actual investments There are some means for this aim such as i energy audits ii developing energy management units in organized industrial zones iii technical expertlevel trainings in which industrial companies attend for establishing energy management system in their facilities On those 3 topics there are certain progress i The pilot audit program was initiated ii The OIZs were selected and equipment tender is ongoing iii The call for expertlevel training was completed and the dates were determined Despite all mentioned progress a little more time is needed to see the actual investments
ISO 50001 and Energy Management System trainings are likely to play a significant role for reducing indirect emissions These trainings would be supportive to take action for reducing energy use by simple measures which do not entail serious investments More information on EnMS trainings is given in part of outcome2

description.narrative: Energy audit program for large industry and SMEs implemented
F Share of energy audits in Turkey leading to actual investments in EE in industry

comment.narrative: Less than 10 to be verified and adjusted within 1st project year
At least 50

1 An audit checklist including around 80 questions about boilers pumps compressed air etc prepared by project consultants was finalized by the contribution of the YEGM experts who had considerable experience in undertaking energy audits in the field The checklist is ready to use for walk through energy audits particularly in the utilities and general systems of the factories The checklist was used during the training of the ESCOs EVD companies and the audit of the Arcelik plant
2 The checklist will be supplemented by more detailed material for certain energyintensive processes especially in iron steel cement ceramics paper and pulp and chemicals industries To find a competent company having experts in these fields an RFP was prepared and submitted to the NPD for his approval in April 2015 The tender is expected to be announced in August 2015
3 Within the context of the developing of an audit methodology the EE auditing guide including audit report template basic principles etc was developed and modified according to ISO 50002 which was issued in June 2014
4 Energy Audits The pilot phase of the energy audit activities was started in February 2015 Nine industrial facilities out of 51 which had previously been invited by GDRE officially applied to be a part of the auditing program Necessary background information of participating industrial companies for the bidding process such as energy consumption production processes the capacity of electricity transformers features of steam systems number of compressors motors etc was collected by YEGM and the bidding process was initiated in January 2015 Seven eligible EVD companies were invited to bid Six of them submitted their proposals on time The contracting was finalized in February 2015 and the preaudits walk through energy audits WTEAs were realized in March 2015 The WTEA reports were collected in April 2015 In May 2015 the evaluation committee held a 2 day meeting to assess the 9 reports Letters providing the feedback from the evaluation committee were sent to the EVD companies The EVD companies revised the reports and submitted the modified versions in June 2015 They were all reevaluated and accepted The EVD companies are now undertaking detailed energy audits After the evaluation of the detailed energy audit reports the new audit program will be designed in the light of lessons learned
5 For further audits there will be a call for proposal including feasibility study supports In this call for proposal the industrial companies will be invited to join the program for i audits ii feasibility studies by committing that they will produce investment projects which will also later be supported by the YEGM The preparations studies are ongoing for this program

activity-description.narrative: To reduce energy consumption and associated GHG emissions in public buildings in Turkey by raising building energy performance standards, improving enforcement of building codes, enhancing building energy management and introducing the use of integrated building design approach.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

1. Average thermal energy consumption in new buildings compared to baseline. 2. Implementation of demo constructions with IBDA resulting in significant energy improvements. 5. Required data, verification processes, and website utilization and relevance to key stakeholders. 6. comment.narrative: In 2000, there were 7.8 million buildings in the country and the total heating area was approximately 900-1,000 million m2. Between the 2000 census and 2008, an additional 750,000 buildings received construction permits , thus bringing the total number of buildings to 8.6 million, bringing the total floor area to approximately 1.7 billion m2, not including unregistered or informal construction. According to TUIK Building Census 2000 and Annual Building Statistics on construction permits 2000-2006, the share of residential buildings stood 86%, while the remaining 14% covered non-residential buildings, including public buildings like schools and government buildings. . Turkey's annual electricity demand has tripled since 1990, reaching 198 TWh in 2008. Electricity use in the residential sector stands at 40 TWh and commercial sector at 23 TWh. Though, the largest share of the building sector’s energy consumption (70% of the total energy mix) belongs to heating and hot water needs, which are met through natural gas, coal, wood and oil.

description.narrative: To reduce energy consumption and associated GHG emissions in buildings in Turkey by raising building energy performance standards improving enforcement of building codes enhancing building energy management and introducing the use of an integrated building design approach
Average total energy consumption for heating cooling ventilation and lighting in new residential and nonresidential buildings

comment.narrative:
Residential 200 kWhm year
Nonresidential 321 kWhm year
Nonresidential 193 kWhm year for buildings built with IBDA

A total of five buildings designed according to the Integrated Building Design Approach were simulated for building energy performances The results achieved were far behind the targets For the SincanEtimesgut Departments of Land Registry and Cadastre Office Building 3732kWhm2yr were achieved whereas for Cezeri Green Technologies High School the result was 2362 kWhm2yr The construction of the buildings were started and the total energy consumptions will be measured
Moreover to achive this objective a Terms of Reference were prepared for developing New Minimum Building Energy Performance Standard MBEPS and Nearly Zero Energy Building nZEB Approach for Turkey
In order to increase the awareness regarding the building codes in Turkey a book prepared by IEA and UNDP was translated to Turkish

description.narrative: Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new buildings to be built during project lifetime 20102015 against the baseline

comment.narrative: 0 tCO2
2 million tCO2

Within the scope of the project 5 different buildings were designed using the Integrated Building Design Approach IBDA These buildings consist of 1 office building for Ministry of Environment and Urbanism and 4 buildings school workshop dormitory sports hall for the Ministry of National Education Tender documents were prepared for both Ministries and tendering procedures were completed by the Ministry of Environment and Urbanism in December 2014 and construction works are ongoing Tendering procedures were completed by the Ministry of National Education in January 2015 and construction works are also ongoing The total project direct emission reductions resulting from the construction of 5 demonstration buildings around 30000 m2 construction area are estimated to be around 29705 tCO2eq over a 20year period In order to reach the 2m tCO2eq emission reduction target design and construction of 67 buildings following the IBDA approach will be adequate This is easily achievable provided that the use of IBDA for new public buildings is adopted by the Government of Turkey
The Ministry of Environment and Urbanism is highly interested in adaptation and implementation of IBDA and thereby its integration to the building bylaws 3 books were pepared for the adaptation and implementation of IBDA in Turkey by 15 experts and the final editing works are ongoing Complementary trainings on the use of IBDA and partnerships with selected universities for promoting IBDA are planned Later a strategy will also be developed to make IBDA mandatory for new public buildings

description.narrative: Building energy consumption energy savings and other results of the project monitored evaluated and reported
The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability

comment.narrative: Insufficient institutional mechanisms in place to ensure sustainability of project results
Project recommendations to ensure institutional sustainability adopted

Besides a communications strategy for effective dissemination of project results and improved awareness raising activities is also developed
A launching meeting is being organized for the demo buildings
New brochures for the integrated design approach key issues has been prepared and published Ministry of Environment and Urbanism distributed the brochures approximately 5000 in their service trainings and will go on sharing the brochures prepared by our project

description.narrative: Costeffective energy efficiency solutions showcased through integrated building design approach application in two demo buildings

Adoption and diffusion level of IBDA
Implementation of IBDA demonstration constructions

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge and application of IBDA

Cost effective energy efficiency solutions are demonstrated through IBDA demonstration buildings
IBDA is promoted through trainings and awareness raising activities

For the 5 different demo buildings the designs were completed and approved by the respective Ministries Ministry of Environment and Urbanization for the office building and Ministry of National Education for school buildings school atelier workshop dormitory and sports hall The tendering procedures were completed and the construction works have been initialized by the Ministry of Environment and Urbanization for the office building in December 2014 For the school buildings the tendering procedures were completed and the construction works have been initialized by the Ministry of National Education in January 2015 Monitoring and Consultancy services in order to provide correct implementation of the project design are ongoing Several visits to the construction site have been accomplished and the construction is closely followed up
Energy Performance Certificates A level Energy Performance Certificates for all buildings from the BEPTR program a public issued building energy performance software were received and Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were produced The simulated energy performances for office building and for school buildings are 37 kWhm2yr and 23 kWhm2yr respectively
Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were prepared according to the approximate cost values and the payback period for the office building was found to be around 6 years and the payback period for the school buildings was found to be around 13 years When the life cycle cost analysis were repeated with the actual costs of the buildings accoring to the bid amounts the payback period for the office building was found to be around 45 years
A team of 15 experts for promotion of IBDA through preparation of an Adaptation Report and an Implementation Guidebook was established The team has produced 3 books with an addition of Priorities and Targets for the Building Performance book All the books are reviewed several times by the experts of the Ministries and comments were received Editing works are ongoing and printing versions are being prepared for all the three books
Complimentary training activities and cooperation with selected universities are also planned for October 2015 The real impact of this outcome is directly related to the adoption level of IBDA by the Government The performance levels of IBDA demonstration buildings are impressive The user behavior and its effect on performance are yet to be seen following the completion of demonstration buildings The performance will be monitored when the operation phase starts

Once the Energy Efficiency in New Buildings Checklist and Guidebook document was completed 4 regional training sessions were organized and completed in June 2014 in order to promote energy efficiency in new buildings More than 600 participants were attended and to increase the number of people to reach the document and the trainings an online training module was developed and uploaded to the website of the Ministry of Environment and Urbanism under Building Inspection System wwwydsgovtr The Ministry is currently working on the checklist to integrate into the legislation Once this checklist is integrated into Building Inspection legislation it will be mandatory to apply the checklist for all new private building project designs and consecutively in constructions This is more or less equal to 100000 new buildings every year
A new RFP document was prepared and will be launched in July 2015 for the development of Minimum Energy Performance Standards MEPS for new buildings and adaptation of Near Zero Energy Buildings nZEB for Turkey and energy efficiency strategy document for buildings

*Hands on training for LULUCF Unit and local foresters under implementation. •MRV methodology identified specifically for forestry sector •Integrated fire management plans for pilot sites prepared. *Equipment and supplies for integrated fire management system are purchased. •Training modules for carbon focused silvicultural activities specific to pilot sites under preparation. •Experimental site plots for carbon focused silviculture plans are identified. •Labs for IPM system established. •Roadmap for identification of carbon protocols and MRV system within forest management plans are prepared. •Biodiversity assessment of 5 pilot sites finalized. •Species specific ecological surveys finalized. *Communication strategy and plan prepared. *Communication and training kit for integrated forest management with printed materials and short films are finalized.

•Hands on training for LULUCF Unit and local foresters implemented at Head Quarter and pilot site level. •MRV methodology identified specifically for forestry sector. Activity data and emission factor definitions decided to be improved in 2016. •Integrated fire management plans for pilot sites prepared. A detailed implementation plan for each pilot site are also prepared and submitted to GDF. •Equipment and supplies for integrated fire management system are purchased and transferred to the GDF. •Training modules for carbon focused silvicultural activities specific to pilot sites prepared. •Experimental site plots for carbon focused silviculture plans identified. •One Lab for IPM system in Mersin established. The second lab for IPM system in Antalya to be established in 2016. •Roadmap for identification of carbon protocols and MRV system within forest management plans prepared. •Biodiversity assessment of 5 pilot sites finalized. •Species specific ecological surveys finalized. •Communication strategy and plan prepared. •Communication and training kit for integrated forest management with printed materials and short films finalized. •Rapid assessment on baseline situation for non-wood forest products and eco-tourism finalized. •Institutional capacity strengthened through 4 study tours at national and local level.

•MRV methodology with activity data and emission factor for each forestry activities under IFM (Improved Forest Management) protocols detailed. •SFM (Sustainable Forest Management) criteria and indicators scaled up at national level. •Collaboration with Yale University for strengthening institutional capacity initiated. •Equipment and supplies for integrated fire management system purchased for upgrading the system. •Trainings for carbon focused silvicultural activities and Integrated Fire Management specific to pilot sites delivered. •Experimental site plots identified in 2015 compared based on carbon benefits and new plots for carbon focused silviculture plans identified for 2016. •Second lab for IPM system in Antalya established. •New management model including carbon, biodiversity, SFM benefits of the project integrated into Gülnar Forest Management Plan. •Report on integrated Forest Management Plan for GaziPaşa submitted. •Gender focused socio-economic studies initiated at 5 pilot sites. •Initial plan for value chain of non-wood forest products and eco-tourism are prepared.

description.narrative: To promote an integrated approach to management of forests in Turkey demonstrating multiple environmental benefits in high conservation value forests in the Mediterranean forest region
Area of forest landscapes in Turkey with integrated forest plans developed and under implementation that deliver multiple environmental benefits biodiversity climate change ha

comment.narrative: 045 mln ha

Project initiated several activities at site level and headquarter level to enable the legislative and organisational structure for ensuring integration at landscape level While the target level at end of the project ie 045 mln ha will be achieved through cumulative effect of all progress at each outcomes current contribution of outcomes is promising with several facts as following i LULUCF unit established and MRV action plan prepared ii Process for amending legislation and site based activities are in line for producing technical and policy level justifications iii site based interventions for mitigation activities ie fire and pest management solar water heating systems and enhancement of carbon stocks silvicultural activities are detailed in an integrated approach at 125000 maps iv rapid biodiversity assessment at all pilot sites started some taxa already mapped along with silvicultural implementation plans

description.narrative: Implementation of forestbased GHG mitigation and carbon sequestration tools within landscape
Carbon protocols designed and completed before during and after implementation of enhancement and mitigation efforts

comment.narrative: No carbon protocol

Introduction of carbon protocols in line with MRV system Output 13 enabling integration of climate change into forest management plans through a central LULUCF Database under Forest Information System FIS Project of GDF

Terms of reference for a national consultant on forest management plans and a national consultant on carbon protocols are prepared and submitted to the GDF Upon technical inputs from the related departments the consultants will be hired ENVANIS system to be upgraded for carbon protocols has been elaborated through several technical workshops and meetings with the Forest Management and Planning Department of the GDF 125000 scale maps of all pilot sites with current forest management functions prepared overlapped with biodiversity data along with fire pest silviculture afforestation action plans A process for ecosystem base multifunctional planning with specific table and optimal situation for climate change and biodiversity was drafted

description.narrative: Fire management and carbon losses from fires

comment.narrative: Suppressionfocused fire management system annual carbon losses at five pilot sites average 3629 tCO2y
Proactive prevention and load management focussed fire management methods at pilot sites generate carbon benefits of 1646 tCO2y over baseline

Site based interventions forest unit based mitigation options fuel management strategies are elaborated with the Department of Fire Combating and academia A detailed plan for integrated fire management system a list of required equipment software and training needs drafted Terms of Reference for national consultant prepared and an Integrated Fire Management consultant hired Yearly intervention plans at all pilot sites are under preparation

description.narrative: Fuel wood removals and associated carbon fluxes

comment.narrative: High levels of legal and illegal fuel wood removals for household consumption especially home heating with resulting annual carbon losses at five pilot sites averaging 18775 tCO2y No alterative system to replace fire wood consumption in place
Expansion of microcredit program into Mediterranean region generates carbon benefits of 13038 tCO2y over baseline

As per the Steering Committee meeting decision and technical workshops with related GDF departments ORKOYs microcredit programme will started after a detailed study on socioeconomic situation of forest villages within pilot sites and a technology assessment for house heating solar systems including solar water heating system are complete Terms of Reference for both services prepared and submitted to the GDF

description.narrative: Integrated pest management IPM and associated carbon fluxes

comment.narrative: No proactive IPM resulting annual carbon losses at five pilot sites averaging 45286 tCO2y
Introduction of IPM methods and establishment of two pest centres generates carbon benefits of 30191 tCO2y over baseline

Location of two pest centres identified Required activities for equipping and running of pest centres with laboratories and early warning system are in progress Site based interventions pestspecific action plans data management of integrated pest management strategy are elaborated with the Department of Pest Management A list of required equipment and training needs drafted A national Integrated Pest Management Consultant was hired Yearly intervention plans at all pilot sites are under preparation

description.narrative: Silvicultural methods consider carbon and biodiversity aspects Assessment of associated carbon benefits

comment.narrative: Carbon benefits not taken into account or measured locations not chosen to maximize connectivity enhancements
Silvicultural approaches at pilot sites generate carbon benefits of 11572 tCO2y along with enhanced connectivity

Locations chosen to maximize connectivity enhancements As a result of field surveys a site of 3919 ha was identified to undertake silvicultural efforts for carbon and biodiversity aspects in 2015 A carbonfocused silviculture consultant and a afforestation consultant were hired A detailed plan for carbon focused silviculture and afforestation action plan at site level with capacity of carbon stocks were prepared Activity plan at site level and forest unit level are under preparation

description.narrative: Policy and institutional framework for integrated forest management within landscape
Forest protected area regulatory framework

comment.narrative: No legal framework defining forest PA expansion and integration within broader landscape
Effective regulatory framework enables GDF to establish forest PAs based on combined SFM criteria including biodiversity and carbon

The GDF and related departments identified needs and process for amending regulation on forest PAs Required data from Component 3 identified to understand the scale and scope of the amendment in the Protected Forests Regulation It is decided to start the legislative works upon justification of biodiversity conservation needs for permanency and integrity through field surveys in the Pilot sites

description.narrative: Forest sector Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action NAMA

comment.narrative: No NAMA
One fully developed NAMA covering 24 million ha Mediterraneanregion forests

The Steering Committee and the LULUCF Unit was consulted on the NAMA issue since the position of Turkey on eligibility is under question As a result of the Steering Committee decision it was decided to undertake consultation with the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation the Focal Point of the UNFCCC to elaborate Turkeys position on NAMA According to the advise from the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation it was decided to wait for official communication from the Secretariat of UNFCCC Once the official communication will be finalised the MoEU will share the decision with the Steering Committee and the LULUCF Unit of the GDF

description.narrative: LULUCF Unit

comment.narrative: No properly capacitated LULUCF Unit in the Government

One adequately staffed and funded LULUCF unit established Capacity needs assessment is under implementation List of names roles and responsibilities and organisational structure are modified according to project needs LULUCF Unit already started their works on INDC calculation of LULUCF sector and other related works in according to the requests from the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation and Ministry of Foreign Affairs Role of LULUCF Unit on forest based MRV and NAMA identified Upon capacity enhancement activities LULUCF Unit will lead the MRV and NAMA related activities

*Brief summary of the national circumstances prepared in line with the Sixth National Communication *Institutional arrangements and level of support relevant to the preparation of the national communications and biennial reports on a continuous basis described *A web-site serving as an e-library including all relevant documents, reports and publications, as well as an electronic portal facilitating the preparation of National Communications and Biennial Reports developed and published under MoEU’s web-site *Worksheets, summary tables for GHG emissions elaborated and needs identified for the BR preparation *List of recommendations to strengthen data collection process, institutional coordination and collaboration, reporting and quality of the inventories prepared *FBR Table 1 on GHG Emissions and Trends prepared *Support provided for strengthening national arrangements and raising awareness to enable the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) *Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) developed by other countries briefly reviewed *Support provided for the identification and drafting of Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) *FBR Table 5 on summary of key variables and assumptions used in the projections analysis prepared *FBR Table 6 on updated greenhouse gas projections ‘with measures’ and ‘without measures’ scenarios prepared *A study on financial, technological and capacity needs and constraints related to climate change as well as on international and national resources allocated for climate change with their associated effectiveness performed using a participatory approach *Updated information on financial resources, technology transfer, capacity building and technical support received from bilateral and multilateral donors, IFCs, Green Climate Fund (GCF) etc. for activities related to climate change prepared *FBR Table 7 on provision of public financial support prepared *FBR Table 8 on provision of tec

*Submission of Turkey's Joint First and Second Biennial Report to UNFCCC as of January 2016 *Providing support to the domestic Measurement, Reporting and Verification (MRV) arrangements in waste sector *Providing support for Turkey’s preparations for the CoP22 *Providing support for the development of an education kit on climate change targeting the teachers at primary and secondary schools

*Information in tabular format consolidated, compiled and Turkey's Joint First and Second Biennial Report submitted to UNFCCC and published as of January 2016 *Institutional arrangements relevant to the preparation of the Greenhouse Gas inventory in waste sector in Turkey described *National capacities, needs and constraints in Greenhouse Gas inventory preparation and MRV arrangements in waste sector in Turkey assessed *International best practices in Greenhouse Gas inventory preparation and MRV arrangements in waste sector reviewed *Individual and institutional capacities strengthened via development of a set of training methodologies and tools and provision of a training of trainers programme on Greenhouse Gas inventory preparation and MRV arrangements in waste sector, in line with UNFCCC Secretariat’s review reports and IPCC guidelines *Reccomendations provided for sustainability of MRV arrangements in waste sector and their replication in other sectors in Turkey *An education kit on climate change targeting the teachers at primary and secondary schools developped *Technical and administrative support provided for strengthening Turkey’s preparations for the CoP22 held in Marrakesh in 2016 (via organisation of a preparatory meeting before the CoP22 and arrangement of side events during the CoP22 to share lessons learned and raise awareness on the best practices carried out in the field in Turkey) *Assistance provided for project proposals preparation to be submitted for international financial resources *Effective monitoring, reporting and preparation for financial audits ensured

seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: POPs elimination activities will take place in Kocaeli.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Major legacy POPs stockpiles (POPs pesticides and current/pending PCB based equipment) eliminated in an environmentally sound manner 2. A long term PCB phase out plan assuring compliance with SC requirements is in place and capacity is in place to eliminate PCB cross contamination in electrical equipment and plans are in place for phase out and elimination of remaining PCBs based electrical equipment. 3. Implemented regulatory framework for addressing contaminated sites and action initiated on POPs contaminated sites. 4. Tracked and quantified continuing reductions in U-POPs release from major industrial sectors. 5. Turkey can claim developed country status respecting POPs and sound chemicals management, with an institutional and regulatory framework fully harmonized with that of the EU and with including active participation as a donor and provider of environmental services to developing countries.

comment.narrative: • Globally significant large POPs pesticide stockpile remains without action beyond securing it and no more than token amounts being destroyed in the medium future. • 500 t of existing PCB based equipment scheduled for export and elimination in 2014 • Approximately 650t of additional PCB equipment identified as requiring phase out and elimination. • No fully qualified national capability for destruction of POPs stockpiles in place. • National inventory of PCB based equipment still being developed. • Existence of PCB cross contaminated transformers identified but no systematic inventory identifying extent of the issue exists. • No clear PCB phase out plan operational with respect to addressing remain PCB issues in accordance with the SC. • No national capability available to treat cross contamination and retain such equipment in service. • Framework legislation covering contaminated sites in place but not yet implemented. • No systematic action on identification and addressing POPs contaminated sites yet taken. • No effective financing mechanism in place to support contaminated site legacy issues • Although data on U-POP emission are available for some sectors, priority sector like I&S still lack of confirmed U-POP emission information and cost/effectiveness of BAT/BEP. • Turkey has initiated a program targeting EU harmonization in this area. • A growing technical and service provider capability in this area exists but is not fully capable of meeting international standards. • No focused international technical assistance programs are in place in this area for developing countries.
•Elimination of 30 t of obsolete pesticide stocks. •Training delivered to 100 professionals in site and risk assessment

•RFQ for the elimination of 30 t stockpile finalized and İZAYDAŞ awarded, contract to be issued. •Inception Workshop held on 16 and 17 November 2015, Procurement Plan, Inception Report and AWP finalized. •Contaminated Sites Training arranged with 180 attendees and held on 3-4 December 2015 under Component 4. •LNOE contracted after a competitive selection. •LIOE contact drafted.

•Lead International Oversight Expert contracted. •Detailed stockpile/ site assessment implemented, operational plans, EA, and tender documents prepared and contract awarded for Merkim POPs stockpile site and infrastructure removal. •Packaging, transporting and environmentally sound destruction of consolidated obsolete pesticides from government agencies established. •Operational and safeguards training for hazardous waste and residual site clean-up delivered. •Facility upgrade investment in materials handling, APC and monitoring infrastructure at the Izaydas facility established. •Test burns undertaken on representative POPs (PCBs and POPs pesticides) at the Izaydas. •Public consultation for design and permitting for above activities at Izaydas supported. •Potential facilities licenced by MoEU reviewed during inception period for upgrading/qualification of existing national POPs destruction capability. •Technical support provided for implementation and administration of three primary systems under regulation. •Training program developed for risk assessment of contaminated sites and technical guideline for contaminated site management prepared.

•Lead International Oversight Expert contracted. •Detailed stockpile/ site assessment implemented, operational plans, EA, and tender documents prepared and contract awarded for Merkim POPs stockpile site and infrastructure removal. •Packaging, transporting and environmentally sound destruction of consolidated obsolete pesticides from government agencies established. •Operational and safeguards training for hazardous waste and residual site clean-up contracted but not delivered yet. •Facility upgrade investment in materials handling, APC and monitoring infrastructure at the Izaydas facility established. •Test burns undertaken on representative POPs (PCBs and POPs pesticides) at the Izaydas. •Public consultation for design and permitting for above activities at Izaydas supported.

- Detailed stockpile/ site assessment completed. - Technical specification for Merkim Site prepared and tendered. - Operational and safeguards training for hazardous waste and residual site clean-up delivered. - Test burns undertaken on representative POPs (PCBs and POPs pesticides) at the Izaydas and test burn report prepared. - Training for contaminated site remediation techniques implemented. - PCB Elimination Tender completed and first lot of PCB containing equipments were eliminated.

comment.narrative:
Percentage of the cases dealt in 2013 (6097 cases out of 7638:%80) Number of recommendations and decision on rejections issued in 2013 (112 in 2013) Number of visitors to OI website in 2013 (76235)

Capacity needs of OI assessed At least two actions for capacity development conducted The strategic plan finalized in line with the capacity assessment report One international event on effective functioning of OIs conducted At least one regional conference for enhancing awareness of NGOs conducted

Capacity needs of OI assessed Three actions for capacity development including the development of internal control mechanisms and performance measurement indicators achieved The strategic plan finalized in line with the capacity assessment report One international event on effective functioning of OIs conducted One regional conference in İstanbul for enhancing awareness of NGOs conducted

- Human rights skills and knowledge including investigative skills, as well as access to human rights jurisprudence in Turkish and greater knowledge and integration of human rights based approaches to programming enhanced among OI staff - Stronger relations with civil society organizations and other public institutions the continuum of the regional conferences (6) with the participation of relevant stakeholders in 2016.

The Capacity Assessment of the Project was completed in early 2016, outlining actions that need to be taken in the short, medium and long terms in the areas of “Legislation”; “Human Rights architecture”; “Communications and Awareness Raising”; “Human Rights Skills and Knowledge”; “Civil Society Partnerships”; and “Staff Development and Training”. These recommendations were determined following and external stakeholder analysis, SWOT analysis, and a staff survey. The UNDP was assured by the OI that agreed points have been inserted into the Strategic Plan of the OI, completing the indicator in the Results Framework of “%50 of the capacity needs of OI reflected to the Strategic Plan of the OI”. Noting that it is the OI’s prerogative to discuss the action points and decide on which to pursue, and that certain action points such as the “human rights architecture and complaints handling mechanisms of different institutions” is outside the direct authority and influence of the OI, the project has shown itself to be useful in providing a platform on which to discuss these issues at a high level. Progress has been made, however, on the issue of training all experts and assistant experts of the OI on a Human Rights Based Approach. The special envoy of the Global Alliance of Human Rights Institutions (GANHRI), Alan Miller, was recruited by the project to train the OI staff. He has recently visited the Institution in Ankara and met with coordinating experts from each of the 5 Ombudsman offices, as well as the training unit and the press unit of the OI. Having gathered information on the level of the experts and certain ideas on case studies, Alan Miller will now create the training programme based on his findings, and will deliver the trainings in January. Later, Alan Miller will draft a short guideline on the HRBA and how to continue using it in evaluations of applications for the benefit of experts at the OI., As for the public awareness raising activities, the regional con

- Human Rights Based Approach training delivered to all experts of the OI - HRBA guidelines developed with experts' participation for continued practical guidance on HRBA - 10 public awareness programs in selected provinces reaching out to NGOs, media, public institutions, academia and mukhtars.

- Legal aid needs of Syrians assessed and road map for improvement developed -Capacity of legal aid service providers to Syrians enhanced - Updated automation system for appointment of legal aid lawyers being sensitive to needs of specific groups of women and children

- Under Outcome V (legal aid needs of the Syrian population), the field visits to Southern provinces of Hatay, Osmaniye, Gaziantep, Kahramanmaraş and Şanlıurfa were completed. In depth interviews were conducted with representatives of Bar Associations, NGOs, Syrian community and state institutions. In total, 63 consultation meetings and focus groups were convened in the project pilot provinces with 109 men and 83 women. A needs-assessment report was drafted by the consultants. Comments and feedback to the report were obtained from the Advisory Committee members, and the report was revised in line with the feedback. Following official approval by the UTBA and the MoJ, the report will be published. The capacity of legal aid service providers to Syrians has not yet been enhanced. This is expected to occur only after the trainings to be conducted by the consultants in the provinces. The Strategy and Road Map to be drafted for the UTBA for the improvement of legal aid services in referred provinces will also take the recommendations report into account. - The field visits for the automation system have been initiated. The expert hired has already travelled to Mardin, which is one out of 5 provinces to be visited, the others being İzmir, Muğla, Samsun, Edirne. She is accompanied by representatives from the UNDP, MoJ, and the UTBA. Interviews are conducted with judges, prosecutors, lawyers, police, state institutions such as the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Family and Social Policies, and their affiliated units. The assessment and recommendations report to be drafted at the end of the visits will in form the proposed adjustments to the Automation system. This is expected to happen in the first half of 2017. - Under Outcome II (enhanced capacity for legal aid lawyers), the first kick-off activity is to be held in Antalya on 10-11 December 2016, bringing together heads of Bar Associations, representatives of legal aid or CCP committees of all bar associations, as

200 CCP attorneys trained on legal aid needs of Syrians 300 CCP attorneys trained on approaching disadvantaged groups in the legal aid provision process 6 regional meetings bringing together judges, prosecutors, lawyers and NGO representatives from 81 provinces together to discuss "common problems, common solutions" in legal aid. Regulation for a new automation system adopted by UTBA

The Needs Assessment under Component 5 have been completed, while all field visits for Component 2 have also been completed. The trainings for all 500 attorneys for under both components will be completed by the end of October
